column4: Whats a nice ultra light version of ubuntu for older machines?
how old ?
its about 5 years and has probably a max of 1 gig of hdd and its likely a HP desktop
my pc is 4 yrs old and runs kubuntu just fine , so ubuntu will probly run very well
you mean 1G of Ram , right ?
yes 1 gig of ram sorry hah didnt mean to say hdd
of course it matters what you intend to run on the pc but 1G Ram is adequate for normal surfing , video , data and video as long as you don't have too much stuff going on simultaneously
its for my cousins fairly computer illiterate crazy girlfriend.
the more spoon feeding the os gives her the better
you'll probly need to spoonfeed for a short while , as long as you set it up to make it easy, but going from windows or mac to ubuntu is quite a change in terms of desktop learning and adapting
it would be so awesome if someone we're to make a youtube video series that just covers ultra basics and than snapped that into some ubuntu "Noobstation" app
actaully kde is closer visually to windows , it's more familiar looking then gnome or unity

yeah fair enough.  I was going through a bad phase of linux mint... I had installed mint on her machine thinking because I had one good experience with it over ubuntu when some package was for some reason broken in the repos.

but at this point the lts version is looking great and working very smoothly on my desktop.  I wish graphics support were to improve but i guess that I can wait another two releases or so for my dual saphire radeon hd 6850's to be supported.
I can't comment on mint , since I've never used it ,
its a nice ui their mint menu is really the biggest difference.
it recognizes that I have two cards but thats as far as it goes.
I tried unity /gnome3 etc , ..just not my cuppa tea,  KDE suits my taste best
I've always found kde just a bit less stable.  I really like where gnome3 is going myself.
yeah in some setups . kde takes a bit more configuring , but the results are gratifying when we get it right
ideally if i could script my mods or something but thats not reliable.
